TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit AutomationEvent extends System.Windows.Automation.AutomationIdentifier

remarks.format:
## Remarks Identifiers of these types are found as fields in various classes to identify events; for example, <xref:System.Windows.Automation.InvokePattern.InvokedEvent>. They are also found in the event arguments passed to UI Automation clients.
It is not possible to create custom events.
## Examples In the following example event handler, the <xref:System.Windows.Automation.AutomationEvent> in the event arguments is compared with the <xref:System.Windows.Automation.AutomationEvent> that identifies the Invoked event.
[!code-csharp[UIAClient_snip#173](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/UIAClient_snip/CSharp/ClientForm.cs#173)] [!code-vb[UIAClient_snip#173](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/UIAClient_snip/VisualBasic/ClientForm.vb#173)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public static hidebysig class System.Windows.Automation.AutomationEvent LookupById(int32 id) cil managed
Public Shared Function LookupById (id As Integer) As AutomationEvent

Docs.summary: Retrieves an that encapsulates the specified numerical identifier.
Docs.returns: An that encapsulates the specified numerical identifier.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Normally, events are identified by an <xref:System.Windows.Automation.AutomationEvent> object. This method can be used by UI Automation providers to create such an object when only the numerical identifier (the <xref:System.Windows.Automation.AutomationIdentifier.Id%2A> inherited from <xref:System.Windows.Automation.AutomationIdentifier>) is known.
